title: Can installment loans be included in bankruptcy?
question: I've drownded myself in installment loans, my paycheck is not enough to cover everything anymore, can I claim bankruptcy?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy adversary proceeding,Debt,Lien,Secured debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Car loan
answers: Bankruptcy is a good way to deal with unsecured debts. Secured debts such as car loans, mortgage payments on a home are treated differently. Your best bet is to click the Avvo tab "Find a Lawyer". Talk with several offering free consultations. Then hire one have excellent client recommendations, who returns your calls promptly and who will discuss fees and other issues on your case w/o a lot of legal mumbo jumbo.

Most debts are dischargeable in bankruptcy, so you should discuss any specific concerns with a bankruptcy attorney.

It really isn't clear what you mean by installment loan. If you are making payments on a car loan, the lender has a lien on you car and you might not be able to keep the car if you don't keep making the payments. Installment loans like payday loans are nothing special in terms of how they are treated in bankruptcy.

If you incurred the loan without the intent to repay it, the creditor could file a lawsuit in bankruptcy called an adversary proceeding to ask the it be carved out from you discharge order.

Yes, you can file for bankruptcy; but we have not nearly enough information to determine for sure how successful that will be. Reading between the lines, however, suggests that you should not have a problem discharging those loans.
